description.narrative: - 6 public schools will be targeted in this project coordination with the Ministry of Education and Higher Education (MEHE), three for environmentally sustainable infrastructure. - Both Lebanese and Syrian refugee students are targeted in this intervention.

Improving the capacity of several Lebanese Schools to identify risks and implement risk reduction and mitigation measures. Furthermore the project aims to improve access to safe water, sanitation facilities, and hygiene practices in these institutions; through environmentally sustainable infrastructure and participatory approaches. And in addition, it aims at improving LRC’s Response Preparedness mechanism though a Multisectoral approach.

In 2013, with the support of UNICEF, a WASH document was issued at national level that addresses the specific situation of WASH public schools in Lebanon and intends to serve as a base for the authorities to set national standards. In 2017, the WHO and UNICEF joint monitoring program (JMP) for WASH was conducted in Lebanon by LRC targeting mainly public schools in urban and rural areas. The study showed that in 2016 around 1,444,983 pupils were enrolled in the public education system at national level. The needs identified through the study were around: water quality and quantity, hygiene promotion, sanitation facilities, and control of vector borne diseases. Additionally, through their presence on the field, the WASH staff and volunteers have reported an increasing need in addressing several WASH-related topics, especially in light of the ongoing and worsening economic crisis.
This project aims at enabling LRC to support vulnerable schools, while developing its internal coordination response process in schools.
